page.name: Topic 3.2: Identifying learning activities
page.content:
Overview

Pre-apprenticeship programs should equip participants with the skills they need to progress into an apprenticeship program or into a similar role with potential for advancement. Programs should help participants acquire academic skills (such as reading, writing, and mathematics), and workforce skills (such as communication, problem solving, and self-management). High-quality pre-apprenticeships integrate both classroom and hands-on learning activities that are relevant to the target industry.

Review the resources listed below to learn more about how different pre-apprenticeship programs develop training and curriculum. 

Recommended reading

  • Construction pre-apprenticeship programs (Aspen Institute). Read pages 7-10 of this report to learn more about how construction pre-apprenticeships approach training and curriculum design, including how they mix classroom and hands-on learning activities.
  • Framework for a high-quality pre-apprenticeship program: IT (Jobs for the Future). Components two, three, and four of this framework examine how IT pre-apprenticeships develop training and curriculum. As you read, think about how all of these components fit together to help programs design training in line with industry standards.
  • Access to opportunity: using pre-apprenticeship programs to connect to registered apprenticeship (California Apprenticeship Initiative). Pages 20-21 of this report contain a summary of how several pre-apprenticeship programs have developed their training and curriculum, as well as academic support services.

Case studies

  • Meeting demand, providing opportunities: a pre-apprenticeship case study (California Apprenticeship Initiative). This case study examines the Central Valley Pre-apprenticeship Training Program. Pages 8-10 outline the program structure, including the delivery of remedial education, support services, and hands-on training.
  • Oregon Tradeswomen curriculum resources (Western Resources Center for Women in Apprenticeship). This program mixes both classroom and hands-on instruction, as well as field trips and certifications.
  • Chicago Women in Trades course overview (Women's Equity Center). This provides another example of how a program integrates different skills, including math, test preparation, workplace readiness, and physical fitness.

Helpful tools

  • RapidSkills Generator (Workforce Intelligence Network). This online database allows users to view skill and competency frameworks for apprenticeship programs across a range of industries and locations.
